newsitem.title: INDIA: India wary of Islamic fundamentalism in region.
newsitem.headline: India wary of Islamic fundamentalism in region.

text.p: India said on Wednesday that the emergence of Islamic fundamentalism in Central Asia would hurt its interests and reiterated support for the collapsed Afghan government of President Burhanuddin Rabbani.
"We continue to recognise President Rabbani," Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral told Asian News International in an interview.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda met Rabbani in Rome while attending the World Food Summit earlier this week.
Gujral said India had sent representatives to meet Uzbek militia leader Abdul Rashid Dostum in his stronghold of Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan.
Dostum heads an alliance against the purist Islamic Taleban militia that also includes forces led by Ahmad Shah Masood, Rabbani's military chief.
Gujral said India wanted "to see that peace comes back and the duly established regime that was Rabbani is placed in position again".

"But at the same time, I would say when we say the Rabbani regime must come in, we are also of the opinion that all elements of Afghan polity must get together and form a government of the type that the Afghan people want and not outsiders," he said.
Gujral accused Pakistan of trying to "destabilise" Afghanistan. Pakistan has denied India's claims that Islamabad backs the Taleban, which captured the Afghan capital Kabul in late September.

"We are interested that there should be peace there. We believe that no outside factors should intervene there, and any emergence of fundamentalism in that region hurts India's interests," the Indian foreign minister said.
